generif.text: Translation/insertion scanning, alanine insertion, and glycosylation site mutagenesis studies of liver sodium/bile acid cotransporter support a topography with nine membrane-spanning or membrane-associated segments.

NTCP adopts a dimeric structure in which individual subunits are functional. Bile salt uptake is influenced by heterodimerization when this impairs NTCP plasma membrane trafficking.

NTCP is a functional receptor for human hepatitis B and D virus.

Data suggest that, in SLC10A1, amino acid residues along one face of transmembrane domain 5 do not play direct role in substrate transport but are critical for sodium/bile acid transport functions of SLC10A1, most likely through helical stability.
This study was conducted to determine which of the 8 cysteine residues of NTCP is responsible for nitric oxide-mediated S-nitrosylation and inhibition of taurocholate uptake.
Polymorphisms in CYP2C9, CYP2C19 and SLC10A1 had minimal lipid-lowering effects.
Knockdown analysis suggested that HBV infection of HepG2-hNTCP-C4 cells was mediated by NTCP.
Human NTCP is a specific receptor for hepatitis B and D viruses, allowing virus entry into hepatocytes.
Viral entry of hepatitis B and D viruses and bile salts transportation share common molecular determinants on NTCP.
findings suggest that the rs2296651 polymorphism in NTCP may predispose the susceptibility to and chronicity of HBV infection
This study suggests that polymorphisms in the NTCP region may be associated with the natural course of HBV infection.
hNTCP is an electrogenic Na(+)-dependent transporter
Computer screening of NTCP inhibitors and non-inhibitors showed no relationship between the drugs and drug induced liver injury.
NTCP is a functional receptor for hepatitis B virus and hepatitis D virus.

Data indicate that retinoic acid receptor (RAR) is crucial for regulating sodium taurocholate cotransporting polypeptide (NTCP) expression that determines permissiveness to hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection.
Interleukin 6 inhibits HBV entry through downregulation of NTCP.

The observation that the pharmacological inhibitors of the NTCP transporter could block HBV entry suggests that NTCP represents an attractive molecular target for therapeutic intervention in HBV infection.
NTCP polymorphism play a critical role in the individual variability of rosuvastatin pharmacokinetics in Chinese healthy males
Liver nuclear receptors, FXR and SHP, and bile acid transporters, NTCP and BSEP, are associated with the progression of NAFLD.
Hepatitis B virus efficiently infects non-adherent hepatoma cells via NTCP, which functions as a virus receptor.
The SLC10A1 (NTCP) S267F variant is independently associated with decreased risk of progression to Liver cirrhosis and Hepatocellular Carcinoma , and resistance to Chronic Hepatitis B infection.
We describe for the first time a mouse liver cell line that, solely upon expression of the hNTCP receptor, becomes susceptible to HBV.
We found a genetic variant (rs4646287) located in intron 1 of NTCP that may be associated with increased risk of HBV infection in Han Chinese
For Tibetans and Uygurs, no association of the three NTCP SNPs (rs7154439, rs4646287 and rs2296651) and their haplotypes with hepatitis B virus chronicity was observed.

Results show that NTCP inhibition suppressed the in vivo spread of HBV infection in the presence of uninfected hepatocytes. Livers in CHB patients contained varying degrees of HBsAg-negative hepatocytes, as evidenced by immunohistochemistry.
In conclusion, NTCP appeared inefficient to mediate infection by serum-derived hepatitis B virus.

the present study indicated that the common variants in the regulatory elements of NTCP may not influence the expression level of SLC10A1 at transcriptional regulation, and ultimately may not be associated with HBV susceptibility.
These results uncover NTCP as a mediator of innate antiviral immune responses in the liver.
The data showed that S267F of sodium taurocholate cotransporting polypeptide is not associated with hepatitis B virus infection, and is not prevalent in the general Moroccan population.
genetic variation at the SLC10A1 locus is not likely a major risk factor of persistent HBV infection among Southern Chinese.

the findings of this study have shown that the S267F variant on the NTCP gene is independently associated with sustained normalization of ALT following treatment with PEG-IFN in patients with HBV infection who are HBeAg-positive.
The results from our study suggest that SLC10A1 mutations should be screened for in individuals with asymptomatic hypercholanemia.
These kinetic results provide important complementary data on the substrate selectivity and specificity of NTCP to transport bile acids.

the S267F variant of NTCP is clinically associated with a lower risk of chronic hepatitis B virus infection and cirrhosis development, which implicates suppressing hepatitis B virus entry could reduce the disease burden.
Results find that hepatitis B virus (HBV) replication cycle starts when HBV enters hepatocytes using NTCP as a receptor.

Among individuals with hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, the sodium taurocholate cotransporting polypeptide (NTCP) genotype frequencies of GG, AG and AA in Taiwanese women are 0.85, 0.15 and 0 while those in men are 0.82, 0.18 and 0, respectively. Genetic variation in the HBV receptor gene (NTCP) is significantly associated with a decreased risk of HBV infection in women.

These findings suggest that host factors unique to HepaRG cells are required for efficient infection by serum-derived HBV, and factors other than NTCP contribute to balanced viral antigen production following infection by cell culture-derived HBV.
The S267F variant for the HBV cell-entry receptor NTCP was associated with increased resistance to HBV infection.

In this study, the authors identified new hepatitis B virus isolates from one homozygous S267F NTCP mutation carrier and confirmed new isolates also use wildtype-NTCP as a cellular receptor. Furthermore, we demonstrated S267F variant of NTCP, though inefficient, is still a functional receptor for hepatitis B virus entry.

we review the current knowledge of the functional role and the molecular and cellular biology of NTCP in the life cycle of the three major hepatotropic viruses, highlight the impact of NTCP as an antiviral target and discuss future avenues of research

NTCP upregulated hepatitis B virus (HBV) transcription via farnesoid X receptor alpha (FxRalpha)-mediated activation of the HBV EN2/core promoter at the postentry step in a manner that was dependent on the bile acid (BA)-transport function of NTCP, which was blocked by MyrB.

The data provide the first molecular evidence supporting that Hepatitis B virus-related hepadnaviruses drive adaptive evolution in the NTCP sequence, including a mechanistic explanation of how NTCP mutations determine host viral susceptibility.

The NTCP S267F variant of the SLC10A1 gene exhibits protective effects against HBV and HDV infection and is associated with a reduced risk of developing to advanced stages of liver cancer and hepatocellular carcinoma.

The authors herein demonstrate that the NTCP p.Ser267Phe variant is a protective factor reducing chronic hepatitis B patient risk for liver failure, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma. A host genetic background carrying NTCP p.Ser267Phe exerts selective pressure on the virus, leading to more variability.

Results show that the sodium taurocholate co-transporting polypeptide (NTCP) rs2296651 polymorphism was associated with a decreased risk of susceptibility to hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection and the development of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

The study highlighted the role of the SLC10A1 S267F variant in the loss of the ability to support hepatitis B virus infection and taurocholate transport activity. Subjects with the AA genotype may escape from hepatitis B virus infection and present decreased cholesterol levels as a consequence of impaired bile acid uptake.
Down-regulation of cell membrane localized NTCP expression in proliferating hepatocytes prevented HBV infection in HepG2-NTCP-tet cells and in liver-humanized mice.
Among Chines pediatric patients with Sodium Taurocholate Cotransporting Polypeptide Deficiency homozygous mutations of the SLC10A1 gene were identified.
The novel missense variant c.595A>C(p.Ser199Arg) enriched the SLC10A1 mutation spectrum and may serve as a new genetic marker for the molecular diagnosis and genetic counseling of NTCP deficiency.

Study showed that NTCP was highly expressed in breast cancer (BC), liver cancer and paracancerous liver tissues. Specific HBV antigens, along with viral DNA/RNA and Dane particles were identified in BC tissue of chronic HB female patients. HBV was able to successfully infect BC tissue and replicate within by binding to NTCP revealing that in addition to the liver, BC tissue may be a second site of HBV reproduction.

reactome.name: Recycling of bile acids and salts
Bile acid and bile salt metabolism

wikipathways.name: Drug Induction of Bile Acid Pathway

summary: The protein encoded by this gene belongs to the sodium/bile acid cotransporter family, which are integral membrane glycoproteins that participate in the enterohepatic circulation of bile acids. Two homologous transporters are involved in the reabsorption of bile acids; the ileal sodium/bile acid cotransporter with an apical cell localization that absorbs bile acids from the intestinal lumen, bile duct and kidney, and the liver-specific sodium/bile acid cotransporter, represented by this protein, that is found in the basolateral membranes of hepatocytes. Bile acids are the catabolic product of cholesterol metabolism, hence this protein is important for cholesterol homeostasis. [provided by RefSeq, Oct 2011].
